questions.question: What is the main idea behind spaced repetition?
options: Reviewing information at increasing intervals to boost retention
Reading material quickly multiple times
Studying all material in one long session
Focusing only on new information each time
questions.explanation: Spaced repetition is designed to review material at increasing intervals to align with the brain’s natural forgetting curve.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the spacing effect?
options: Learning is best done in one long study session
Reviewing material frequently with no breaks is optimal
Information is better retained when study sessions are spread out over time
Immediate repetition leads to long-term memory
questions.explanation: The spacing effect shows that spreading out study sessions helps memory consolidate better over time.

questions.question: Why does spaced repetition save time compared to traditional study methods?
options: You study only once per topic
It eliminates the need for reviewing altogether
It focuses reviews only when you're about to forget the material
You can skip hard topics
questions.explanation: Spaced repetition reduces wasted effort by targeting reviews right before you're likely to forget something.

questions.question: What is one recommended tool for using spaced repetition effectively?
options: Canva
Google Docs
Anki
Slack
questions.explanation: Anki is a popular app that uses spaced repetition algorithms to schedule optimal review intervals automatically.

questions.question: How should you adjust your review intervals as you become more familiar with the material?
options: Review less often at first, then more frequently later
Maintain the same interval regardless of memory strength
Increase the interval between reviews as recall improves
Stop reviewing once you've seen the material twice
questions.explanation: Spaced repetition increases the time between reviews as your memory strengthens, maximizing efficiency and retention.
